snippet: Catching an insider trader is usually a good thing. But when the investigation results in allowing a crime to take place, that can be troubling, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: What if the government knows a crime is about to take place but does nothing to stop it and instead allows the crime to happen so it can gather additional evidence for a later prosecution? When the crime is insider trading, perhaps the fact that there are no individual victims justifies allowing someone to use confidential information to earn illegal profits. But there is still something troubling when a crime that can be easily stopped is allowed to occur.

headline.main: Questions for the Government in an Insider Trading Case

abstract: Taking time off is a first step. Learning to simply, and deeply, relax is just as important, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column.
snippet: Taking time off is a first step. Learning to simply, and deeply, relax is just as important, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: My first vacation epiphany occurred while taking my two dogs for a walk on the beach at 6 one evening in early August. I’ve always considered walking the dogs obligatory but not especially enjoyable, and I fobbed it off on my wife as often as possible, since she seemed, mysteriously, to enjoy it. But on this night, with the waves lapping on the shore and almost no one in sight, I found myself in a state of deep quiet and contentment. I was happy, nearly rapturous, just walking and taking in the scene.

headline.main: What I Learned on My Vacation

abstract: Dollar General takes its bid for Family Dollar directly to shareholders. | Microsoft near a deal for the maker of Minecraft. | Fed’s newly proposed rules put pressure on banks. | Detroit clears a bankruptcy hurdle.
snippet: Dollar General takes its bid for Family Dollar directly to shareholders. | Microsoft near a deal for the maker of Minecraft. | Fed’s newly proposed rules put pressure on banks. | Detroit clears a bankruptcy hurdle.
lead_paragraph: Dollar General said on Wednesday that it was taking its $9.1 billion offer for Family Dollar directly to shareholders, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. The move could further complicate Family Dollar’s deal agreement to sell itself to Dollar Tree for $8.5 billion. In a statement, Dollar General said it was offering to acquire all of Family Dollar’s shares for $80 each. That is the same bid that Family Dollar rejected last week, contending that the deal it agreed to with Dollar Tree had a better chance of passing muster with antitrust regulators. A hostile bid is likely to, at the very least, delay any deal between Family Dollar and Dollar Tree.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Dollar General Goes Hostile

abstract: Emilio Botín’s ability to combine risk-taking with deep caution allowed him to keep his grip on Santander until his death at the age of 79, Peter Thal Larsen of Reuters Breakingviews writes
snippet: Emilio Botín’s ability to combine risk-taking with deep caution allowed him to keep his grip on Santander until his death at the age of 79, Peter Thal Larsen of Reuters Breakingviews writes
lead_paragraph: Emilio Botín transformed Banco Santander from a regional Spanish lender into a global giant. He was a merger mastermind who usually got the upper hand. With slicked-back hair and red tie, he flew in a private jet, conferring with presidents and prime ministers as easily as bankers and chief executives. Yet unlike many of his peers during European banking’s boom years, Mr. Botín also had a cautious streak. It is that, rather than his swashbuckling style, that allowed him to keep his grip on Santander until his death at the age of 79.

headline.main: Botín’s Swashbuckling Style Hid a Cautious Streak

lead_paragraph: A Senate hearing examining the federal agency that oversees car safety will feature testimony from government officials, safety advocates and a representative from the automobile industry.The hearing, chaired by Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, is planned for Tuesday, and will delve into the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s implementation and enforcement of vehicle safety laws, as well as the agency’s handling of the crisis that has engulfed General Motors. The company has recalled more than 29 million cars since January and failed for more than a decade to report to regulators and the public a defective ignition that has been linked to 13 deaths.

abstract: This crossword was the most-discussed puzzle at Lollapuzzoola 7, a tournament held on Aug. 9 in New York City, and there are some people who still haven’t forgiven Patrick Blindauer for it. Hint: Pay attention to the title of the puzzle.
snippet: This crossword was the most-discussed puzzle at Lollapuzzoola 7, a tournament held on Aug. 9 in New York City, and there are some people who still haven’t forgiven Patrick Blindauer for it. Hint: Pay attention to the title of the puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., here’s the thing: I watched a lot of people solve this puzzle — or try to solve it — at Lollapuzzoola last month, and the results made even the judges grading the puzzles weep. So if you’re still wondering what just happened to you, this is the guy (below right) you should be mad at. And yes, I totally get the irony of my having taken his photograph with a lit light bulb over his head. Only someone as devious — sorry, I meant only someone as creative as Mr. Blindauer could have come up with a puzzle like this.

lead_paragraph: General Motors has told car dealers to stop delivery of certain 2015 Chevrolet Corvettes because they may have faulty air bags and parking brake cables. The automaker will fix driver’s side air bags in about 2,000 Corvettes because they could separate from their steering wheels. Another 800 Corvettes, most of which are at dealerships, are being held back from buyers because they may have been built with defective rear parking brake cables, increasing the risk that parked cars could roll away. Automotive News reported that G.M. was issuing two additional recalls for the vehicles, according to the stop-sales orders sent to dealers, but neither has been publicly announced. Alan Adler, a G.M. spokesman, would not confirm them.

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The maker of one of the costliest drugs in the world announced on Monday that it had struck deals with seven generic drug makers in India to sell lower-cost versions of the medicine — a $1,000-a-pill hepatitis C treatment — in poorer countries.

headline.main: Maker of Costly Hepatitis C Drug Sovaldi Strikes Deal on Generics for Poor Countries
headline.print_headline: Deal Struck on Generics of Costly Hepatitis C Drug

abstract: Of all the dramas that entrepreneurs discuss with one another over drinks, the merging of personal relationships with business seems to cause the most pain.
snippet: Of all the dramas that entrepreneurs discuss with one another over drinks, the merging of personal relationships with business seems to cause the most pain.
lead_paragraph: I spent a recent night consoling an associate who had fallen out with her best friend. They tried to start a business together, and she quit her high-paying job to do it. Three months in, the friend had yet to commit full-time and wasn’t pulling her weight. They couldn’t agree on how to split either the tasks or the ownership stakes. Tension built and eventually exploded, and the business died before it was born. Their 15-year friendship was over.

headline.main: The Problem With Going Into Business With a Friend

abstract: The Apple Watch is both a product and the embodiment of Apple’s values — taste, trust and utility — that have long guided the company’s product and design decisions.
snippet: The Apple Watch is both a product and the embodiment of Apple’s values — taste, trust and utility — that have long guided the company’s product and design decisions.
lead_paragraph: Watching Timothy D. Cook last week as he introduced the Apple Watch to the world was almost touching, in his channeling of his predecessor. The back-and-forth pacing of the stage, the hand gestures, the cadence of his speech and the script unabashedly filled with superlatives — “We set out to build the best watch in the world” — were all reminiscent of the late Steven P. Jobs.

headline.main: What the Apple Watch Says About Apple

abstract: Alibaba’s bankers may raise the price range of the initial public offering this week. | William Ackman plans to list a fund in Amsterdam. | Heineken rejected a takeover approach made by SABMiller. | Apple’s chief gave an interview to Charlie Rose.
snippet: Alibaba’s bankers may raise the price range of the initial public offering this week. | William Ackman plans to list a fund in Amsterdam. | Heineken rejected a takeover approach made by SABMiller. | Apple’s chief gave an interview to Charlie Rose.
lead_paragraph: INVESTORS HUNGRY FOR ALIBABA I.P.O. | With the Alibaba Group expected to price its initial public offering on Thursday, investors are lining up to get a piece of the Chinese e-commerce giant. The flood of orders has been even stronger than expected. Just five days into the company’s journey to promote itself to prospective buyers, Alibaba’s underwriters told their sales staffs at the end of last week that they planned to close orders for the I.P.O. by this Wednesday, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. Given the intense interest, the company’s bankers may eventually raise the price range for the offering, pushing it past a fund-raising goal of $21.1 billion. That could make it the biggest I.P.O. of all time.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Investors Hungry for Alibaba I.P.O.

The puzzle is an original collaboration by Zandra Vinegar, a recent graduate of MIT who lives, does math, builds furniture, and teaches in Berkeley, Calif., and Rafael Cosman, who is in his senior year at Stanford University, where he studies computer science.

abstract: Fraud in the market for penny stocks continues unabated, two criminal cases filed last week show, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
snippet: Fraud in the market for penny stocks continues unabated, two criminal cases filed last week show, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: In his celebrated portrayal of fraudulent sales practices in “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Martin Scorsese did not show the victims who bought the penny stocks that fueled the profits of Jordan Belfort and the brokers at Stratton Oakmont. One would think that a blockbuster movie might teach investors a lesson about trusting such brokers, but fraud in the market for penny stocks continues unabated, as two criminal cases filed last week show.

headline.main: Greed Continues to Fuel Penny Stock Frauds

abstract: A regional tourism organization has begun a campaign in which the city comes out of its closet.

abstract: Allergan made a small measure of peace with its would-be acquirers. | Calpers said it would eliminate all of its hedge fund investments. | Fielding strong demand, Alibaba Group raised the price range for its I.P.O. | Beer brewers could be contemplating another round of deal-making.
snippet: Allergan made a small measure of peace with its would-be acquirers. | Calpers said it would eliminate all of its hedge fund investments. | Fielding strong demand, Alibaba Group raised the price range for its I.P.O. | Beer brewers could be contempl...
lead_paragraph: ALLERGAN’S OLIVE BRANCH | The Botox maker Allergan on Monday night made a small measure of peace with Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management, the pair pursuing a $53 billion hostile takeover bid, when the three companies agreed that Allergan would hold a planned special meeting on Dec. 18, DealBook’s David Gelles reports. At the meeting, Allergan shareholders will have a chance to vote out the majority of the board, a move that could open the door to a takeover. The meeting was already set for that date, but there was a chance it could have been delayed because of litigation related to the takeover bid. Valeant and Pershing Square also agreed to drop pending litigation against Allergan in Delaware, where they had sued to force the meeting.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Allergan’s Olive Branch

abstract: The Canadian company has posted an operating loss of $2.4 billion over the last five years.
snippet: The Canadian company has posted an operating loss of $2.4 billion over the last five years.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Steel Canada was granted creditor protection on Tuesday, the latest chapter in its tumultuous recent history. U.S. Steel said that the Canadian company, known as Stelco before its purchase in 2007, has posted an operating loss of $2.4 billion over the last five years. With the filing, the Canadian unit’s results will no longer be included in U.S. Steel’s financial statements. In 2009, U.S. Steel shut down the Canadian operation and locked out its workers while demanding pension changes. That prompted a lawsuit from the government of Canada, charging that the company had failed to live up to foreign investment laws. An agreement to make further investments in Canada ended that action, although the company continues to battle unions. A lawyer for U.S. Steel Canada told the Ontario Superior Court that it had liabilities of between 3.86 billion and 4.3 billion Canadian dollars ($3.52 billion and $3.9 billion), and assets worth between 1.9 billion and 2.3 billion Canadian dollars, according to The Globe and Mail. The largest creditor is U.S. Steel, which the court was told is owed 1.6 billion Canadian dollars. It will provide the subsidiary with up to 185 million Canadian dollars to keep it operating until the end of 2015.

headline.main: U.S. Steel’s Canada Subsidiary Files for Creditor Protection
headline.print_headline: U.S. Steel’s Canada Subsidiary Files for Creditor Protection

lead_paragraph: ALIBABA MAKES ITS DEBUT | The Alibaba Group raised nearly $21.8 billion in its initial public offering last night, as investors rushed to buy a piece of the company that is poised to continue dominating China’s burgeoning e-commerce industry, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. The shares priced at $68 each, the top of an already raised range, giving the e-commerce behemoth a market value of about $168 billion — much more than eBay, Twitter and LinkedIn combined. The stock sale was among the largest on record, surpassing offerings from Facebook and General Motors. Alibaba could still raise more money if its underwriters make use of an overallotment option to sell more shares.

lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday proposed changes to new rules that will govern food safety in the United States. In an effort to account for concerns raised by small brewers, artisanal cheese producers and other food producers, the agency revised provisions for water testing, as well as those on manure, compost and spent grains. Brewers had objected to rules requiring them to write food safety plans for the spent grain they sell as animal feed. The changes will be open to public comment for 75 days; final rules are to be issued in 2015.

lead_paragraph: ALIBABA’S I.P.O. AFTERMATH | For months, investors eagerly awaited the Alibaba Group’s public market debut. Now, with the Chinese e-commerce giant’s first day of trading solidly in the rearview mirror, nearly everyone is likely breathing a sigh of relief. After pricing at $68 a share, Alibaba’s stock finished Friday up 38 percent, at $93.89, giving the company a market value of $231 billion, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The company officially set the record for the biggest initial public offering ever, after its bankers on Friday decided to exercise a so-called green shoe option, allowing them to increase the size of the deal by 15 percent, from $21.8 billion to $25 billion.

lead_paragraph: The Justice Department went on a bit of a charm offensive last week to emphasize to the public that prosecutions for corporate misconduct should not end with just a settlement with the company, which these days usually means paying a hefty fine that causes its stock price to rise. abstract: The victim compensation program disclosed that 21 death claims had been deemed eligible for payment. That is two more than found eligible a week ago.
snippet: The victim compensation program disclosed that 21 death claims had been deemed eligible for payment. That is two more than found eligible a week ago.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from accidents involving General Motors cars with a defective ignition switch has edged up again. In a weekly update of claims filed to the victim compensation program run by the compensation expert Kenneth R. Feinberg, the program disclosed that 21 death claims had been deemed eligible for payment. That is two more than Mr. Feinberg found eligible a week ago and significantly more than the 13 deaths the company had estimated for months. G.M. has given Mr. Feinberg sole discretion to determine the number of eligible claims for deaths and injuries associated with the faulty switch, which can cause power to cut out in a moving car, disabling air bags, power steering and power brakes. G.M. recalled 2.6 million cars with the switch this year, more than a decade after engineers inside the company first spotted a problem. The latest numbers show a total of 16 eligible injury claims, including four in the most serious category of injury — those resulting in quadriplegia, paraplegia, double amputation, permanent brain damage or pervasive burns.

headline.main: Deaths From Faulty Switch in G.M. Cars Edge Higher

Kessler write in DealBook. After it sold shares worth $6 billion after taxes in the Alibaba Group, which went public last week, the once-mighty Internet giant is at a crossroad, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles write. Yahoo could use the proceeds from the Alibaba share sale to go on an acquisition spree to help reinvent itself and regain relevance. But the company’s previous takeover efforts have yielded few obvious gains, leaving shareholders more eager to receive the bulk of the cash rather than see it used for acquisitions.

abstract: William H. Gross abruptly leaves Pimco. | A.I.G. case sheds new light on bailout. | DreamWorks Animation in sale talks with SoftBank. | Allergan shareholders speak out.

lead_paragraph: BOND KING DEPARTS | William H. Gross, who built Pimco from scratch into one of the biggest money managers in the world, made waves in the business world on Friday when he abruptly quit the firm he founded to join the Janus Capital Group, DealBook’s Matthew Goldstein writes. The exit came after Mr. Gross learned in recent weeks that top executives at Pimco and Allianz, the German insurer that owns it, had grown tired of his leadership and were weighing a change. In particular, there were concerns that his eccentric management style ‒ he wore sunglasses while giving a presentation at a conference and used his monthly investment letters to share intimate details ‒ was becoming a distraction.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Bond King Quits

lead_paragraph: Could Lehman Brothers have been saved? Government officials have argued that the Federal Reserve did not have the legal authority to rescue the big investment bank, leaving it instead to die overnight. Now, new accounts of events from 2008 are casting the firm’s collapse in a different light, James B. Stewart and Peter Eavis write in The New York Times. The decision not to rescue Lehman, in hindsight, let problems at one bank snowball into a full-blown panic. Why, given all that happened, was Lehman the only bank that was not too big to fail?

abstract: Among the advisers to eBay on its proposed breakup is Goldman Sachs. By most of the relevant measures of corporate spinoff data, Goldman is the No. 1 adviser.

headline.main: EBay’s PayPal Plans Bolster Goldman’s Status as Top Spinoff Adviser

abstract: Darden Restaurants directors have paid a steep price for refusing to give in to the demands of shareholder activists pushing for change, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
snippet: Darden Restaurants directors have paid a steep price for refusing to give in to the demands of shareholder activists pushing for change, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Gestures of futile nobility seem mostly confined to the movies these days. And yet the directors of Darden Restaurants, the owner of Olive Garden and other quintessentially American restaurant chains, may have decided that they would rather commit corporate suicide than give in to the demands of two activist shareholders, Starboard Value and the Barington Capital Group. It would be touching if it didn’t appear to be so inexplicably foolish.

headline.main: In Trying to Save Darden, a Board Sealed Its Own Demise
headline.print_headline: In Trying to Save Darden, Its Board Sealed Its Own Demise
